author: Fuseworks Media
title: Claim that need for social houses reducing 'total rubbish'
text:
Fuseworks Media Monday, 19 October, 2015 - 11:03 
Many people are being denied state housing and pushed towards non-government agencies to mask the real need, says New Zealand First. 
"Facts and statistics are being twisted by Minister for Social Housing, Paula Bennett," says New Zealand First Spokesperson Darroch Ball 
"First, people in need of a house are being shuffled off to social providers, often because there is no suitable state house for them. 
"Second, the number of people being classed as ineligible for a state home remains high and thresholds for qualifying for a house remain unchecked. 
"These two facts do reduce the number on the social housing register as Minister Bennett claims, but it is not a true reflection of need. It is a manipulated result to suit the government’s message. 
"Only greater independent scrutiny across the entire process will reveal the true picture. 
"New Zealand First has a member’s bill in the ballot that requires the Better Public Service target results to be independently audited by the Office of the Auditor-General. 
"Minister Bennett has previously welcomed greater scrutiny of her statistics. We challenge her then to put her full support behind our Better Public Service Target Results Independent Audit Bill, in order to show she truly stands by all her statements."
